awd_titl_txt: Coupling of Gravity Waves and Convection, and Their Impacts on the Dynamics and Predictability of Multiscale Processes Associated with Moist Baroclinic JetFront Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This study seeks to study the coupling of gravity waves and moist convection, focused on impacts to the dynamics and predictability of multi-scale processes associated with moist baroclinic jetfront systems through high-resolution observational analysis and ensemble simulations.  This research will advance our understanding of the relative roles of gravity waves and moist convection regarding severe and extreme weather at middle latitudes, and potentially improve the predictability of tropical systems.

Major objectives of this research include: (1) the characterization of the global distribution, source, structure, propagation and amplitude of tropospheric and stratospheric gravity waves, along with their energy and momentum fluxes, using analyses and forecasts from numerical weather prediction (NWP) models; (2) understand the potential impacts of gravity waves and convection on atmospheric energy spectra slopes at the mesoscales and examine the resolvability of gravity waves in NWP models with 1-100 km grid spacing; and (3) to explore the impacts of gravity waves and their interaction with moist convection on the multi-scale atmospheric predictability.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
“Coupling of Gravity Waves and Convection, and Their Impacts on the Dynamics and Predictability of Multiscale Processes Associated with Moist Baroclinic Jet-Front Systems” 

Project Outcome Report

The ultimate goal of this research is to study the coupling between gravity waves and convection and their mutual impacts on upper-level jet-front systems. The project has also examined this coupling in relation to tropical cyclones and tropical waves. The primary research tools are high-resolution observational and modeling analyses and ensemble simulations. As a supplement to the original project, this project also joins the Prediction of Rainfall Extremes Campaign In the Pacific (PRECIP), an NSF-funded international field campaign. This project’s primary objective within the field campaign is to explore the dynamics, observability and predictability of multiscale extreme rainfall events under moisture-rich environmental conditions through assimilating both simulated and field-campaign airborne and ground-based radar, dropsonde and other measurements in addition to standard in-situ and remote observations that are routinely available.

The research activities of this project have yielded multiple outcomes, including a total of 28 peer-reviewed journal publications and one book chapter, and more than 50 conference, workshop, and invited seminar presentations. It has led to the training and professional development for four graduate students, as well as two post-doctoral researchers, who have now started tenure-track assistant professorships at the University of Oklahoma and the Pennsylvania State University.

Major activities and findings of the project are detailed as follows:

  1. Fundamental understanding on the predictability and error growth dynamics of moist baroclinic waves under varying baroclinic and convective instabilities, and with different initial perturbation amplitudes and scales.
  2. Improved understanding on the predictability and error growth dynamics of severe weather events under varying synoptic forcing, and with different initial perturbation amplitudes, scales, and structure.
  3. Real-time execution of the PSU WRF-EnKF data assimilation and forecasting system during the summers of 2020–2022 in support of the PRECIP campaign with the assimilation of all-sky infrared radiances from geostationary satellites.
  4. Further exploration on the benefits and issues with the assimilation of all-sky infrared radiances from geostationary satellites for extreme weather prediction, and how they contribute to the forecast errors of extreme weather, including in the context of tropical cyclones.
  5. Improved understanding of how gravity waves interact with diurnally offshore-propagating moist convection in the Maritime Continent.
  6. Discovery of a new form of interaction between islands of the Maritime Continent, whereby diurnal gravity waves couple with moist convection over multiple islands and multiple days by virtue of their propagation speed relative to the diurnal cycle.
  7. Improved understanding of how clouds and radiation interact, and how this interaction accelerates the formation of tropical cyclones, specifically in anvil and stratiform clouds.
